My friend! — forgive me! — 'twas my love alone</br>Which urged my transport in this uncouth verse,</br>Sighed out the ill-chose syllables in tone,</br>And bade me thus my wretchedness rehearse.
Surely I've felt each different form of woe,</br>And, in each mode, have borne affliction's pangs!</br>In every varied shape the Proteus know,</br>In every form have felt her direst fangs!
Oh!  AMARANTHA! — not to meet again!—</br>At once forget each sympathizing glow—</br>Alas! — thou hearest me not — my cries are vain!</br>In vain my sighs!  my wretchedness!  my woe!—
But, yet, Oh!  purest soul; — yet, e'er thour't fled,</br>One emanation to my spirit dart;</br>One small, small portion of thy virtue shed,</br>That I may feel thy semblance on my heart.
Where thou residest my spirit longs to go,</br>And my soul fain would dwell with thee above!</br>My heart, bent down with solitude and woe,</br>Desires, with thee, to taste a SAVIOUR'S love!

How have we lived!  how loved!  ah!  must we part!</br>Oh could yon ardent Seraph drop his plumes!</br>The heavenly prize should straightway wing my heart,</br>To pierce with thee the star-bespangled domes!
What holy themes have erst employed that tongue!</br>What godly thoughts that more than human mind!</br>Praise borne on that in heaven-dissolving song,</br>From this a prayer wafted on every wind.
Ah!  go not yet!  must AMARANTHA leave</br>The dearest object of her earliest love?</br>Must she descent, so blooming, to the grave?</br>So early join her kindred saints above?
How pleasant e'en in death! — that sinking eye</br>Which never looked on vice — that purest breast</br>Which virtue only taught to heave a sigh,</br>Has pointed long for its eternal rest!
See, with what prayers she darts her soul to heaven,</br>(Collect the dying accents as they fall)</br>"Oh God — Redeemer!  be my sins forgiven!</br>To thee I come — my love!  my hope!  my all!"
Oh, can I e'er forget the lovely maid!</br>When stretched upon the bed of girding pain;</br>While, with her arm around my neck, she said,</br>"Farewell, beloved!  'till we meet again!
"'Till we exalt our unexampled love</br>Into one fountain of eternal praise;</br>'Till we unite our every power above,</br>To sing our JESUS in unceasing lays!"
Hark! — from yon time-worn, mossy spire, I hear</br>The dismal knell of AMARANTHA'S coarse:</br>Lo!  'twixt the trees I see the slow borne bier—</br>Each nodding plume her virtuous worth deplores.
The pale-faced orbit of the moon displays</br>A pleasing horror o'er yon low-shorn green,</br>And gives her borrowed  feeble-chearing rays</br>To aid the solemn sadness of the scene.
The long-drawn isle — and sorrow-cloathed tomb—</br>The ragged trophy — and the marbled bust—</br>The smoaky tapers adding to the gloom,</br>Along the heaps of monumental dust.—
The dying echoes, sounding through the height,</br>Feebly protract the dirge's doleful strain</br>The dismal howlings of the bird of night,</br>And the slow pacing of the sable train.
How all-uncertain is the hope of bliss!</br>The thought of future happiness how vain!</br>The worlds beyond the grave (alas!  not this)</br>May dwell in joy, without a sense of pain!
Hope held to view a round of circling years,</br>Array'd in bliss, and glittering with delight,</br>Shewed me a balm for worlds of vexing cares,</br>To still each woe, and make each sorrow light!
My soul at ease, as if of bliss secure,</br>As if possessing to its farthest went,</br>Looked on encreasing happiness as sure,</br>Fraught with a wish for more than heaven could grant.
Then didst thou strike! — Oh GOD!  thy will be done!</br>Thy dispensations cannot but be right,</br>However feebly by weak wretches known,</br>Howe'er imperfect in our darkened sight!
Resigned I'll bear the ruthless hand of woe,</br>Resigned bereft of AMARANTHA'S love,</br>May but my sorrows terminate below,</br>And JESU'S mercies crown my soul above!
And now, Oh!  fairest of thy sex, farewel;</br>Thou summit of my earliest hope!  adieu!</br>One tear must fall, one pang the sorrow tell,</br>Of me bereft of happiness and you!
Is AMARANTHA hurried on her bier?</br>Who can restrain the tribute of a sigh?</br>Who can call back the sorrow-shrouded tear,</br>Or stop the gushing torrent of the eye?
EPITAPH.</br>Traveller!  seek not the goodness of the fair,</br>Upon the surface of unfeeling stone—</br>Ask of the honest heart — 'tis graven there—</br>Perhaps you'll find it written on your own.
Ask of the poor, along the village street;</br>Ask of the sick, within the impoverished cot;</br>Ask every weeping object, which you meet,</br>If her benevolence can be forgot?</br>
